DOCNAME: CASE OF S.H. v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 3 (in case of expulsion)
JUDGES: Giovanni Bonello;Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Mihai Poalelungi;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza
TEXT: CARDINAL . DATE GPE is a remote kingdom in the GPE , which borders GPE and GPE . According to a census carried out in DATE , the current population is CARDINAL , of whom PERCENT are estimated to be ethnic NORP . The majority of ethnic NORP are NORP , while the PERSON , who account for PERCENT of the population , are predominantly NORP .

CARDINAL . It is believed that the ethnic NORP ( sometimes referred to as GPE , meaning “ southerners ” ) settled in southern GPE in DATE and DATE . They were granted NORP citizenship by LAW of DATE . In DATE , however , a Government census led to the branding of many ethnic NORP as illegal immigrants . There were reports that many ethnic NORP who had previously been recognised as NORP were forced to sign “ voluntary migration certificates ” , thereby forfeiting their citizenship under NORP law . Local PERSON leaders responded with anti - government rallies demanding citizenship and inciting attacks against government institutions . DATE , CARDINAL ethnic NORP fled to refugee camps in GPE alleging ethnic and political repression .

CARDINAL . Since DATE GPE has been ruled by the NORP hereditary monarchy . Although traditionally an absolute monarchy , in DATE the country has witnessed significant political reform . In DATE a draft of the country 's first constitution was unveiled , which introduced major democratic reforms . NORP elections for seats to the country 's first parliament were completed in DATE and the King ratified the country 's first constitution in DATE .

CARDINAL . The refugee population are housed mostly in ORG - funded camps in eastern GPE . In DATE , after DATE of failed bilateral talks between the NORP and ORG to repatriate the refugees , many opted for third - country re - settlement with the help of ORG and ORG ( “ ORG ” ) . CARDINAL NORP refugees have now been resettled . GPE has offered to resettle CARDINAL refugees from GPE over DATE , and a number of other countries have volunteered to host a further CARDINAL . GPE , however , has not agreed to the repatriation of any of the refugees . Those who attempted to return to GPE illegally were returned to the refugee camps in GPE by NORP border police . Some refugees managed to cross the border into GPE in order to stage protests , but all were eventually sent back .

CARDINAL . GPE 's transition to a constitutional democracy has not been an entirely smooth one . A wave of bombings rocked GPE in the run - up to the DATE parliamentary elections , and security forces believed that a number of insurgent groups from among the NORP refugees were responsible .
CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He is a NORP national who claims to be of NORP ethnic origin .

CARDINAL . The applicant states that he was employed by ORG as an office assistant on DATE . On DATE , he was asked to produce a security clearance certificate ( SCC ) . He approached the domestic authorities for the SCC and was refused . He sought the SCC until DATE but was unable to obtain one .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant further states that on DATE , when he attended his village DATE census , he and his family were declared non - nationals and ordered to leave GPE immediately . When he refused to surrender his national identity card he was detained for DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant states that he was dismissed from his job with ORG on DATE because he did not have the required SCC . When he went to Thimphu , the capital of GPE , to challenge this decision he was told to return to his village and obtain papers concerning his status . He was refused these papers and harassed at checkpoints on his journey as he did not have an identity card .

CARDINAL . He states that he was arrested on DATE for no reason and detained until DATE . During this period he alleges that he was beaten regularly with wooden sticks , kicked from behind while suspended upside down , and forced to undertake hard labour . There is no indication that he sustained any permanent scarring as a result . He was released after he had signed voluntary migration papers and was given an ultimatum to leave GPE within TIME . The applicant left GPE for GPE . He stayed there from DATE until DATE , when he travelled to GPE . He was met on arrival by his sister and brother - in - law , who had been granted asylum in GPE in DATE and are now NORP citizens . The applicant 's brother - in - law had been a human rights activist in GPE and had criticised the Government in the course of CARDINAL interviews with ORG .

CARDINAL . The date on which the applicant claimed asylum in GPE was disputed in the subsequent domestic proceedings . The applicant stated that he claimed asylum on DATE , while ORG maintained that it was on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Secretary of ORG for ORG refused the asylum claim . Although he accepted that southern NORP of NORP origin were the subject of discrimination , he did not accept that the applicant was of NORP origin . He also did not accept that the bank would have allowed the applicant to work for DATE without the required SCC . He noted that no evidence had been produced supporting the claim of arbitrary arrest or ill - treatment in detention . The applicant had left GPE through normal immigration channels on his own passport and the failure to seek leave to remain in GPE cast further doubt on his credibility .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed . The Special Adjudicator refused the appeal on DATE . He accepted that the applicant was ethnic NORP but held that that in itself was not sufficient to establish persecution . He did not accept the applicant had experienced the difficulties that he claimed . In particular , he noted that the applicant 's visa application stated that he was working for ORG rather than ORG , and contrary to his claim that he was detained between DATE and CARDINAL DATE , his bank book showed wage payments from his employer up to DATE . The Adjudicator further found that the applicant was not stateless : he had a valid NORP passport and there was no evidence to indicate that he had been declared a non - national .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed to ORG . The appeal was dismissed on DATE as the ORG held that the Adjudicator had been entitled to find as he did on the evidence before him and that no error of law had been made . The ORG also found that the question of statelessness would be resolved practically as ORG would not remove someone unless his home country would accept that he was a national .

CARDINAL . Permission for leave to appeal to ORG was refused on DATE on the ground that the Adjudicator had not made any error of law when he found that the applicant 's evidence was unreliable and that he was not stateless .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant made further representations to the Secretary of ORG . He referred to a report by the chair of ORG in GPE which detailed the persecution of ethnic NORP in GPE and argued that he risked prosecution under LAW DATE for denigrating GPE by claiming asylum . He further argued that this risk would be increased by his association with his brother - in law . Finally , he submitted that his passport was not proof of NORP nationality and that the NORP authorities would consider that he had forfeited nationality by living outside GPE since DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Secretary of ORG refused to consider the applicant 's representations as amounting to a fresh asylum claim . The asylum claim had been treated in confidence and no documentation obtained from the NORP authorities to effect the applicant 's return to GPE would indicate that the applicant had applied for asylum . In respect of the applicant 's brother - in - law , the Secretary of ORG noted that this claim had already been considered by ORG . The remaining points in the applicant 's representations were not significantly different from the material already considered and created no reasonable prospect of success .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Government of GPE issued a travel document for the applicant which was valid for DATE and allowed him to travel from GPE . ORG attempted to remove him on DATE but a ORG injunction prevented the removal as the applicant 's legal processes were still outstanding . On DATE the Government of GPE issued a second temporary travel document to the applicant , which was also valid for DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE further representations were made to the Secretary of ORG which , inter alia , stated that the applicant 's parents had been expelled from GPE . On DATE , these representations were also rejected as not amounting to a fresh asylum claim since no evidence had been submitted in support of the applicant 's submissions .
CARDINAL . On DATE an open letter from ORG was made available which set out the organisation 's concerns regarding the return of the applicant . It stated :

“ This is the first case of its kind of which the organisation is aware that such a travel document has been issued . It is assumed that this unique travel document has been issued because of a request from the GPE government . However , the very fact that [ the applicant 's ] case has been highlighted in this way puts his safety at particular risk were he returned to GPE . ”

CARDINAL . Copies of email correspondence between the applicant 's representatives and ORG High Commissioner for Refugees confirm that the latter made representations to ORG on the applicant 's behalf in or DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant sought permission to apply for judicial review of the Secretary of ORG 's decision of CARDINAL DATE . Permission was refused on DATE as the application disclosed no arguable grounds for judicial review . The Deputy High Court judge also found that the applicant 's submission that he would be at greater risk on account of the travel document had not been made out .
CARDINAL . Permission to renew the application to ORG was refused on DATE .
CARDINAL . DATE , the applicant lodged an application before this Court . Removal directions for TIME were then deferred . On DATE the second travel document issued by ORG expired .

CARDINAL . On DATE fresh removal directions were set for CARDINAL DATE . On DATE the President of the ORG to which the application was allocated decided to apply Rule CARDINAL of ORG and indicate to the Government of GPE that the applicant should not be expelled until further notice .

CARDINAL . Appeals from decisions of the Secretary of ORG for ORG in asylum , immigration and nationality matters are now heard by ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) , which replaces the former system of ORG and ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) . Country guideline determinations of both the ORG and ORG are to be treated as an authoritative finding on the country guidance issue identified in the determination until expressly superseded or replaced by a later country guideline determination .

CARDINAL . In the country guideline determination of DG ( Risk – NORP ) GPE CG [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL , promulgated on DATE , the ORG accepted that persons of ethnic NORP origin were discriminated against in GPE but held that the discrimination did not amount to persecution . It did not , therefore , accept that the NORP minority were persecuted by reason of their NORP origins alone . Rather , each case had to be looked at on its own individual circumstances . In that particular case the claimant had argued that he was stateless , having been deprived of his citizenship by virtue of LAW DATE . The ORG found , however , that if the claimant was permitted to re - enter GPE , he would likely be treated in the same way as any other member of the NORP minority . It was not satisfied that he would not be recognised as a citizen of GPE .

CARDINAL . Council Directive CARDINAL/CARDINAL/EC of DATE ( on minimum standards for the qualification and status of third country nationals or stateless persons as refugees or as persons who otherwise need international protection and the content of the protection granted ) has the objective , inter alia , of ensuring ORG Member GPE apply common criteria for the identification of persons genuinely in need of international protection ( recital CARDINAL of the preamble ) . In addition to regulating refugee status , it makes provision for granting subsidiary protection status . Article CARDINAL(e ) defines a person eligible for subsidiary protection status as someone who would face a real risk of suffering serious harm if returned to his or her country of origin . Serious harm is defined in DATE as consisting of : ( a ) death penalty or execution ; ( b ) torture or inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment of an applicant in the country of origin ; or ( c ) serious and individual threat to a civilian 's life or person by reason of indiscriminate violence in situations of international or internal armed conflict . LAW was transposed into domestic law by the Refugee or Person in Need of International Protection ( Qualification ) Regulations CARDINAL .
IV . RELEVANT COUNTRY INFORMATION
ORG

CARDINAL . The LAW was adopted on DATE . Country Information Reports pre - dating its adoption indicated that while the ORG 's human rights record was improving , the ethnic NORP minority were still subjected to discriminatory treatment . According to ORG on ORG in GPE , published on DATE , such treatment included the following : the requirement that all citizens wear the traditional dress of the ethnic majority ; the prohibition of political parties organized by ethnic NORP citizens ; the requirement that ethnic NORP meet very strict criteria to be considered “ genuine ” NORP and obtain citizenship and security clearances in the form of LAW ; and the requirement in southern GPE for ethnic NORP to perform a disproportionate amount of compulsory labour .

CARDINAL . A report published by ORG on DATE and entitled “ Freedom in the World DATE GPE ” further stated that while the Government had made substantial progress on political reform over DATE , the ethnic NORP continued to face discrimination . The report indicated that :

“ Conditions for NORP speakers in GPE have improved somewhat , but several major problems remain . According to a DATE ORG report , ethnic ORG must obtain certificates verifying that they do not present a threat to the state in order to enter schools , receive health care , take government jobs , or travel within GPE or abroad . Schools in the south restrict even those NORP speakers with certificates . ”

CARDINAL . For the ethnic NORP who remained in GPE , concerns related predominantly to the risk that those who could not obtain LAW would be unable to access employment and healthcare and in some cases would be declared non - nationals . On DATE ORG published a report entitled “ GPE 's Ethnic Cleansing ” , which reported that :

“ A NORP government census in DATE classified PERCENT of GPE 's current population as ' non - nationals ' , meaning that they are not only ineligible to vote , but are denied a wide range of other rights . An ethnic NORP non - national living in GPE told ORG , ' they do n't ask me to leave , but they make me so miserable , I will be forced to leave . I have no identification , so I can not do anything , go anywhere , get a job . ' ”
CARDINAL . The DATE ORG report further recorded that :

“ The government restricted emigration and prohibited the return of citizens who left the country . The country 's citizenship laws state that persons who have left the country of their own accord , without the knowledge or permission of the government , or whose names are not recorded in the citizenship register maintained in ORG ( ORG ) , would not be considered citizens of the country . Some dissidents and human rights groups claimed that the law was created specifically to deny citizenship to ethnic - NORP . Human rights groups also allege that some ethnic NORP with relatives in the camps faced insurmountable bureaucratic challenges and were denied IDs for procedural reasons . As a result , these individuals were unable to participate in the election process . ”

CARDINAL . ORG The first stage in GPE 's transition to a constitutional democracy was the election of CARDINAL candidates to ORG . The DATE elections were monitored by ORG , which published its final report on DATE . While the mission expressed concern that during the campaign period candidates were prevented from discussing citizenship and security clearance issues , it concluded that :
“ The election of CARDINAL ethnic NORP ( PERSON ) candidates was a positive sign for an inclusive ORG that can address issues of concern for the country 's minority citizens . ”

CARDINAL . The LAW was adopted on DATE . Article CARDINAL grants all persons the right to life , liberty and security of persons ; the right not to be deprived of property except for a public purpose and on payment of fair compensation ; the right to equality before the law and to equal and effective protection of the law without discrimination on grounds of race , sex , language , religion , politics or any other status ; the right not to be compelled to belong to another faith by means of coercion or inducement ; the right not to be subjected to torture or to cruel , inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment ; the right not to be subjected to arbitrary or unlawful interference with his or her privacy , family , home or correspondence ; the right not to be subjected to capital punishment ; the right not to be subjected to arbitrary arrest or detention ; and the right to initiate legal proceedings to enforce these rights . Further rights and freedoms are guaranteed only to NORP citizens . These include the right to freedom of speech ; the right to freedom of thought , conscience and religion ; the right to vote ; and the right to freedom of movement .

CARDINAL . However , the LAW further provides that notwithstanding the rights conferred by it , nothing in LAW prevent the ORG from imposing reasonable restrictions by law when it concerns the interests of the sovereignty , security , unity and integrity of GPE ; the interests of peace , stability and well - being of the nation ; the interests of friendly relations with foreign GPE ; the incitement to an offence on the grounds of race , sex , language , religion or region ; the disclosure of information received in regard to the affairs of the ORG or in discharge of official duties ; or the rights and freedom of others .
CARDINAL . Citizenship of GPE is governed by LAW , which provides as follows :
Article CARDINAL
Citizenship
A person , both of whose parents are citizens of GPE , shall be a natural born citizen of GPE .
A person , domiciled in GPE on or before the Thirty - First of DATE and PERSON and whose name is registered in the official record of ORG shall be a citizen of GPE by registration .
A person who applies for citizenship by naturalization shall :
Have lawfully resided in GPE for DATE ;
Not have any record of imprisonment for criminal offences within the country or outside ;
Be able to speak and write PERSON ;
Have a good knowledge of the culture , customs , traditions and history of GPE ;
Have no record of having spoken or acted against the Tsawa - sum ;
Renounce the citizenship , if any , of a foreign ORG on being conferred NORP citizenship ; and
Take a solemn Oath of Allegiance to the LAW as may be prescribed .
The grant of citizenship by naturalization shall take effect by a ORG of ORG .
If any citizen of GPE acquires the citizenship of a foreign State , his or her citizenship of GPE shall be terminated .
Subject to the provisions of this LAW , ORG shall , by law , regulate all other matters relating to citizenship .
CARDINAL . ORG on ORG in GPE , published on DATE , indicated that :

“ The transition to a parliamentary democracy helped the human rights situation to improve considerably ; however , there were continued difficulties with the regulation of religion , and some discrimination against the ethnic NORP minority . ”
CARDINAL . The same report , under the heading ' ORG , stated that :

“ The constitution provides for the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and freedom of association , with the caveat that membership to associations that are " harmful to the peace and unity of the country " are excluded . In DATE , according to SAHRDC , a group of ethnic NORP staged a protest in PERSON as part of their continuing effort to pressure the government to resolve the NORP refugee problem in GPE . Police arrested the demonstrators and handed them to the LOC police of LOC in GPE . ”
CARDINAL . Under the heading ' ORG , the report continued as follows :

“ The law provided for freedom of association , and the government permitted the registration of some political parties and organizations . However , the government did not permit political parties organized by ethnic NORP citizens . ”
CARDINAL . Under the heading ' ORG , Internally ORG , and ORG , the report added :

“ The law does not address forced exile . Although the government officially does not use formal exile , there were CARDINAL ethnic NORP living in refugee camps in GPE and GPE after a government campaign in DATE forced them out of the country . While the government has agreed , in principle , to accept many into the country , they have declined requests to visit the refugee camps . In DATE many political dissidents freed under government amnesty stated they were released on the condition that they depart the country . The government denied this assertion . Many of those released subsequently registered at refugee camps in GPE , while some relocated to GPE .

The government restricted emigration and prohibited the return of citizens who left the country . The country 's citizenship laws state that persons who have left the country of their own accord , without the knowledge or permission of the government , or whose names are not recorded in the citizenship register maintained in ORG ( ORG ) , would not be considered citizens of the country . Some dissidents and human rights groups claimed that the government wrote the law specifically to deny citizenship to ethnic - NORP . Human rights groups also alleged that some ethnic NORP with relatives in the camps faced insurmountable bureaucratic challenges and were denied identification cards for procedural reasons . As a result , these individuals were unable to participate in the election process . ”
CARDINAL . The Asian Centre for Human Rights was even more critical of the regime . In its “ LOC Human Rights Index DATE ” it reported that :

“ Despite the introduction of the first ever Draft Constitution providing limited CARDINAL - party democracy ... , GPE essentially remains a repressive regime run by the PERSON family . GPE officially discriminates against the minorities . A landlocked and closed country , little information on the human rights violations was available . ”
CARDINAL . It further notes that :

“ The draft constitution does not provide any safeguard to preserve , protect and promote the arts , custom , knowledge and culture of the minorities . It has maintained deadly silence on providing any affirmative action programme for minorities . ”

CARDINAL . Finally , ORG indicated , in a report entitled “ ORG Values DATE commenting on budding democracy in GPE ” , that while the LAW appeared to promise improvements , those living in the southern parts of GPE still met with discrimination .

CARDINAL . The applicant submitted a number of expert reports prepared for the purposes of the domestic proceedings which considered the specific risk to him on return . In a report prepared on DATE , PERSON , a Professor of NORP and ORG at ORG ( ORG ) at ORG , indicated :

“ It is difficult to predict precisely what would happen to [ the applicant ] were he to be returned to GPE . I myself am not aware of any such case to date . The fact that the government of GPE is willing to facilitate his return to GPE by issuing a travel document should not be taken as an indication that he would be able to resume anything resembling his former life in that country , or even be able to remain in the country for very long .

GPE is small , thinly populated and bureaucratically centralized , and anonymity would be impossible . Wherever he went it would be widely and generally known that he was a returned asylum seeker and anti - national . Even those Lhotshampas who never left GPE face discrimination in the fields of employment , education , freedom of movement , and citizenship ... It is extremely difficult to imagine any meaningful rights or any real security being granted to an individual who left the country without permission , thereby forfeiting his citizenship , and subsequently spoke ill of the king 's and the government 's record on human rights , thereby committing treason . ”

CARDINAL . In CARDINAL statements dated DATE and DATE , ORG indicated that it did not consider it safe to return the applicant to GPE . In particular , ORG had concerns about the sustained and cumulative discrimination against southern NORP which could amount to persecution and severe risk to the right to life . In addition , it was concerned that those who sought asylum in other countries and raised issues about human rights abuses in GPE while out of the country could face prosecution under LAW . In the second report , ORG raised an additional concern : namely , that the travel document issued to the applicant was the first of its kind , and it questioned why the Government would issue such a document when it had consistently denied the right to return of CARDINAL southern NORP evicted in DATE .

CARDINAL . In a report dated DATE , ORG stated that it did not believe that the physical , legal or material security of the applicant could be guaranteed on return to GPE . The report noted that ethnic NORP faced ongoing and severe discrimination in all aspects of daily life in GPE , and there was reason to believe that those whose relatives had left GPE would be particularly targeted . On DATE a letter from ORG confirmed that a person who talked against King , country and Government was a “ non - national ” and committed an offence under LAW DATE which was punishable by life imprisonment .

CARDINAL . In a letter dated DATE ORG emphasised that it had not been granted access to the areas of potential return in GPE , and as it would be impossible to monitor any returns process , it did not promote returns .

CARDINAL . The applicant also submitted CARDINAL reports by PERSON , Co - ordinator of ORG ( GPE ) . The initial report is dated DATE , and the follow - up reports are dated DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE . In her report of DATE , PERSON noted that those southern NORP who had remained in GPE continued to suffer severe and sustained discrimination , amounting to persecution . In particular , she stated that since DATE access to government services , such as education , healthcare , and employment in public services , had all been dependent on producing a “ Non - Objection Certificate ” , a security clearance certificate from the police which confirmed that they had not spoken or acted against ORG , and did not have any relatives who had done so .
CARDINAL . Ms Carnegie further stated , at paragraph CARDINAL , that :

“ The situation of those southern NORP remaining within GPE remains very insecure . Their citizenship status has been eroded in successive census exercises throughout DATE and into DATE . The nationwide census held in DATE and published in DATE show that of a total population of CARDINAL , CARDINAL are NORP citizens , whilst the remaining CARDINAL are said to be foreign nationals . There are growing concerns that this latter category , appearing for the first time in GPE 's population figures , may represent an effective ' de - nationalisation ' of many southern NORP remaining within GPE . ORG is currently issuing new citizenship identity cards to NORP nationals , and there are serious concerns that a large proportion of the southern NORP will be excluded from this process . Without such cards , they will be denied the right to vote and to enjoy by law the rights guaranteed by LAW . ”

CARDINAL . With regard to the applicant 's situation , PERSON stated that the travel documents issued by the NORP government offered no guarantee that his nationality rights and other rights would be recognised on his return . It was not possible to determine exactly what the applicant 's fate would be , in the absence of a known precedent , but it was reasonable to conclude that he would be at significant risk as a failed asylum seeker for whom ORG had twice applied for travel documents .

CARDINAL . Finally , PERSON considered the risk to the applicant under the DATE LAW . She concluded that were the applicant returned to GPE , he would face imprisonment , torture or inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment under ORG of DATE , which stated that whoever engaged or attempted to engage in treasonable acts against King , people or country , either within or outside GPE , should be punished with death or life imprisonment . Moreover , according to the LAW , whoever creates or attempts to create misunderstanding or hostility between the ORG and the people of GPE and people of any foreign countries with which GPE has peaceful and friendly relations shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to DATE .

CARDINAL . In her final report , dated DATE , PERSON was specifically asked to address the question of whether there had been any change in the treatment of the ethnic NORP in GPE following the adoption of the LAW . In her opinion , she stated that there had been no significant change following the adoption of LAW . Moreover , she believed that the clear distinction made in the LAW between rights afforded to “ all persons ” and rights afforded to “ citizens ” gave permission for the marginalisation and exclusion of non - citizens from the mainstream of society .

CARDINAL . Finally , she referred to a DATE report by ORG entitled “ GPE : Land of Happiness for the Selected ” , in which the ORG indicated that Lhotshampas still living in GPE continued to face discrimination amounting to breaches of their civil and political rights as well as their social , economic and cultural rights . Consequently , the ORG did not believe that it was safe to return GPE to GPE as the ORG could not guarantee their physical , legal and material security .
